abstract.para: This section answers common questions about the new installer and deployment process.

section.title: What happened to &yast;?
section.para: For installation, &slea; 16 comes with installer images based on a new technology called &agama;. The single purpose of &agama; is to install a new system and not to serve as a management tool like &yast; was.
&agama; images are delivered in several flavors. To name several of them:

listitem.para: full – with a full copy of the package repositories for all product flavors
remote installation – deployment using the PXE client

section.para: &agama; also supports unattended installation while reatining a large degree of compatibility with &ay; regarding the file format and data schema. However, &agama; is not a fully compatible drop-in replacement for &ay;. Even though, you can use existing profiles to a large degree, adjustments to the profiles is expected. There is also a new, much more powerful profile schema based on json/jsonnet.

You can install &slea; 16 using repositories provided by a local &rmt; server inside the customer's network. There is no &rmt; version based on &slea; 16 yet. However. &rmt; 15 is fully supported as installation source for &slea; 16.

section.title: Where is the rescue system?
section.para: The &agama; installation images no longer come with a separate rescue system. In a future release of &slea; 16, we plan to provide a separate image for this purpose.

To enter a rescue shell (without starting &agama;), you can use the live media. Alternatively, you can use the &agama; image to access the installed for diagnosis and repair in any of the following ways:

listitem.para: boot the installation image, switch to another virtual console and log in as &rootuser;
boot the installation image and open a terminal window
boot the installation image and before starting the Linux kernel, add 3 to the kernel CLI. This will boot into runlevel 3, skipping the graphical system and thus the installer.

section.para: Any of these methods will give you a root shell that should allow you to access your root partition. Many of the tools needed to repair/recover a potentially broken installation should be available inside the &agama; live media.
